The greatest common divisor of any rational number's numerator and denominator equals 1.

type: ‚àÄ (self : ‚Ñö), self.num.natAbs.Coprime self.den
name: Rat.reduced
docString: The greatest common divisor of any rational number's numerator and denominator equals 1.

This theorem states that for any rational number, the absolute value of its numerator and its denominator are coprime. In other words, the greatest common divisor of the numerator and the denominator of any rational number is 1. This is a form of simplifying rational numbers where the numerator and the denominator have no common factors other than 1, also known as "reduced form".

type: ‚àÄ (self : ‚Ñö), self.num.natAbs.Coprime self.den
name: Rat.reduced
docString: This theorem states that for any rational number, the absolute value of its numerator and its denominator are coprime. In other words, the greatest common divisor of the numerator and the denominator of any rational number is 1. This is a form of simplifying rational numbers where the numerator and the denominator have no common factors other than 1, also known as "reduced form".

In a Euclidean domain with decidable equality, the greatest common divisor of any two elements divides the first element.

type: ‚àÄ {R : Type u} [inst : EuclideanDomain R] [inst_1 : DecidableEq R] (a b : R), EuclideanDomain.gcd a b ‚à£ a
name: EuclideanDomain.gcd_dvd_left
docString: In a Euclidean domain with decidable equality, the greatest common divisor of any two elements divides the first element.

This theorem states that for any natural number `n` and any unit `u` from the group of units of integers modulo `n` (denoted as `(ZMod n)À£`), the value of `u` (obtained using the `ZMod.val` function and then coercing `u` to integer) is coprime with `n`. In other words, the greatest common divisor (gcd) of `ZMod.val ‚Üëu` and `n` is 1, meaning that they share no common factor other than 1.

type: ‚àÄ {n : ‚Ñï} (u : (ZMod n)À£), (‚Üëu).val.Coprime n
name: ZMod.val_coe_unit_coprime
docString: This theorem states that for any natural number `n` and any unit `u` from the group of units of integers modulo `n` (denoted as `(ZMod n)À£`), the value of `u` (obtained using the `ZMod.val` function and then coercing `u` to integer) is coprime with `n`. In other words, the greatest common divisor (gcd) of `ZMod.val ‚Üëu` and `n` is 1, meaning that they share no common factor other than 1.
